content.question: A student wants to modify model 1 so that it represents an <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> double helix instead of a <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> double helix. Of the following possible changes, which would be most effective in making model 1 look more like <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> than <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: Changing the sequence of the base pairs

Changing the deoxyriboses to riboses by adding <math alttext="O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> groups
Changing the shapes of the nitrogenous bases to match those shown in model 2
Changing the sugar-phosphate backbone to a ribbon, as shown in model 3

content.answer: Changing the deoxyriboses to riboses by adding <math alttext="O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> groups
